# Task

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is one way you could solve this problem using Julia DataFrames package. You can install it via the Pkg REPL mode with `]add DataFrames`. 

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map((dt)->Dates.format(dt,"y"), df[:dt]) * map((dt)->Dates.format(dt,"m"), df[:dt])
end
```

This function `add_yearmonth` takes a DataFrame as input and adds a new column `ym`. It uses the built-in `map` function to apply the anonymous function `(dt)->Dates.format(dt,"y") * Dates.format(dt,"m")` to each element in the column `dt`.

The function inside map, `(dt)->Dates.format(dt,"y")`, extracts the year from the DateTime and formats it as a string with "y" format code. Similarly, `(dt)->Dates.format(dt,"m")` extracts month from DateTime and formats it as a string with "m" format code.

The `*` operator concatenates these two strings. The result is then assigned to the new column `ym`.

You can use this function on your DataFrame like so:
```julia
add_yearmonth(df)
```
